Introduction

Pyoderma gangrenosum (PG) is a rare, neutrophilic dermatosis characterized by painful, rapidly progressing cutaneous ulcers with undermined borders.  The etiology of PG is not fully understood, but it is commonly associated with systemic disease, including inflammatory bowel disease, rheumatoid arthritis (RA), and malignancies (eg, solid organ, hematologic).

Pathophysiology



The exact pathogenesis of PG remains unclear, although it is believed to result from proinflammatory immune dysregulation (eg, increased expression of certain interleukins) and genetic susceptibilities (eg, inflammasome mutations).

Risk factors



The risk for PG is higher in patients with the following conditions:



  • Inflammatory bowel disease (eg, Crohn disease, ulcerative colitis)
  • Inflammatory arthritis (eg, RA)
  • Malignancy (solid organ or hematologic)


In addition, PG occurs at higher rates in young/middle-aged women.

Clinical presentation



PG starts as an inflammatory papule, pustule, bulla, or nodule (

image 1
) that rapidly progresses to form an expanding ulcer with a purulent base and an irregular, violaceous border (
image 2
).  PG can present with a single lesion or multiple lesions, usually on the trunk or lower extremities.  Nearly 30% of cases are triggered by local trauma (pathergy).  Patients often report pain that seems out of proportion to the lesion.



Most patients with PG have an associated systemic disorder such as inflammatory bowel disease, inflammatory arthritis (eg, RA), or a malignancy (hematologic or solid organ).

Pathology



Histologic features of PG are nonspecific; nevertheless, biopsy of the lesion is recommended to rule out other conditions that may present similarly (see Differential Diagnosis section).  Features that PG may exhibit include perifollicular inflammation, intradermal abscess, and epidermal and dermal necrosis.

Diagnosis and evaluation



PG is a clinical diagnosis because biopsy findings are nonspecific, and no other definitive diagnostic testing exists.  A panel of tests should be performed when PG is suspected to exclude other similar conditions and to screen for systemic diseases that often accompany PG.  Therefore, the following tests are recommended in the evaluation process:



  • Incisional lesion biopsy for histological examination and microbial stains/cultures
  • Antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibodies and antiphospholipid screen to check for small vessel vasculitis and antiphospholipid syndrome as causes of cutaneous ulceration
  • Colonoscopy to evaluate for associated inflammatory bowel disease
  • Complete blood count and serum immunofixation electrophoresis to evaluate for associated hematologic malignancies/disorders
  • Antinuclear antibody titer and rheumatoid factor to check for associated inflammatory arthritis

Differential diagnosis



  • Venous insufficiency ulcers:  typically found at the medial malleoli.  Unlike PG, these ulcers are mildly painful and usually accompanied by chronic stasis changes (eg, brawny discoloration, dermal atrophy, varicose veins) (
    image 3
    ).
  • Basal cell carcinoma:  can ulcerate in advanced disease but typically presents initially as a painless, slowly growing, pearly papule with telangiectasias and a rolled border in a sun-exposed area (
    image 4
    ).  Histologic examination reveals nests of basaloid cells (resembling the stratum basale) with a high nuclear-cytoplasmic ratio, which is not present in PG.
  • Squamous cell carcinoma:  starts as a scaly papule in a sun-exposed area.  As the lesion enlarges, ulceration may occur (
    image 5
    ).  Histologic examination reveals nests of dysplastic keratinocytes, not seen in PG.
  • Erythema nodosum:  is an acute panniculitis that presents with tender, erythematous nodules/plaques on the lower extremities (
    image 6
    ).  Like PG, erythema nodosum is also associated with systemic disease (eg, inflammatory bowel disease, internal or hematologic malignancies); however, the lesions do not ulcerate but instead resolve without scarring after 2-8 weeks.
  • Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome:  is an autoimmune disorder characterized by systemic hypercoagulability (eg, deep vein thrombosis, ischemic stroke).  Thrombosis of small cutaneous vessels causes painful cutaneous ulcerations, necrosis, and infarction (eg, digital gangrene).  Antiphospholipid screen (recommended in the evaluation of suspected PG) is positive.
  • Small vessel vasculitis (eg, microscopic polyangiitis, granulomatosis with polyangiitis):  can affect the skin and typically presents with purpura in the lower extremities (
    image 7
    ).  Scattered bullae and small ulcers may form, but large, isolated ulcers and pathergy are not typical and are more suggestive of PG.
  • Ecthyma gangrenosum:  is a skin infection most frequently due to Pseudomonas aeruginosa.  It presents with hemorrhagic pustules with surrounding erythema that evolve into necrotic ulcers and occurs most commonly in the setting of profound neutropenia and bacteremia (
    image 8
    ).  Unlike in PG, patients typically have signs of systemic infection (eg, fever), and pain is significantly less prominent.
  • Necrobiosis lipoidica:  presents with asymptomatic, yellow or pink-brown plaques usually in the pretibial areas of patients with diabetes mellitus (
    image 9
    ).  Over time, the plaques become atrophic, and some may ulcerate.  Histologic examination reveals granulomatous dermatitis, a feature not seen in PG.
  • Sporotrichosis:  is a fungal skin infection acquired through breaks in the skin, typically from rose bushes or other plant materials.  It presents as a small papule or nodule (
    image 10
    ) at the inoculation site (usually hands or arms), which then may enlarge, ulcerate, and lead to additional lesions along draining lymphatics, a feature not seen in PG.
  • Fixed drug eruptions:  typically present as sharply demarcated, red-brown round/oval patches or plaques that are pruritic or mildly painful (
    image 11
    ).  The lesions usually recur in the same location each time an offending drug (eg, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, tetracyclines) is taken.  Unlike PG, the lesions typically do not ulcerate.

Management

Pharmacological therapy



Topical and systemic therapies are available, with the choice dependent on the severity/extent of the disease.



  • Limited disease (lesions <3 cm, one or few in number) is treated with high-potency topical corticosteroid therapy (eg, betamethasone, clobetasol, fluocinonide) until the lesion heals.
  • In contrast, extensive disease requires systemic corticosteroid therapy (eg, prednisone) because application of topical therapy becomes impractical.  Cyclosporin can be used when systemic corticosteroid therapy is contraindicated (eg, diabetes mellitus).  Severe cases often require the addition of another immunosuppressive therapy, such as tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitor (eg, infliximab, adalimumab) or mycophenolate mofetil (which blocks DNA synthesis of T/B lymphocytes).

Wound care



Wound care measures to optimize healing include cleansing the wound daily with a mild antiseptic, using nonadherent dressings that create a moist environment (to promote wound healing), and using a barrier cream (eg, petrolatum, zinc oxide) to protect the skin around the ulcer edges.



In addition, trauma to and around the wound should be avoided because it can delay healing or induce new PG lesions (pathergy).  For the same reason, surgical debridement of the wound generally should be avoided.

Complications



  • Secondary bacterial infection (which presents with worsening pain, malodorous discharge, warmth, and fever)
  • Scarring (which can be extensive, especially after large ulcers heal)
  • Disability (caused by chronic pain and impaired mobility when wounds are large or extensive)

Prognosis



The prognosis varies depending on the severity of the disease, the presence of underlying conditions, and the timeliness of treatment.  With treatment, 50% of patients achieve wound healing within a year.  However, lesions can recur, even after long periods of remission.



PG may increase the risk for death, likely due to a combination of treatment complications (eg, chronic immunosuppression), associated underlying disorders (eg, malignancy), and health consequences of chronic inflammation.

Summary



Pyoderma gangrenosum is a rare, inflammatory skin disorder that is often associated with inflammatory bowel disease, inflammatory arthritis, and malignancies (hematologic and solid organ).  Pyoderma gangrenosum starts as an inflammatory papule, pustule, vesicle, or nodule that rapidly progresses to form an expanding ulcer with a purulent base and an irregular, violaceous border.  The diagnosis is made clinically after other causes have been ruled out by lesion biopsy and laboratory evaluation.  Management of local lesions includes topical high-potency corticosteroid therapy.  Oral corticosteroid therapy, with or without additional immunosuppressive therapy (eg, tumor necrosis factor alpha inhibitor therapy), is recommended for severe, extensive disease.
